section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read the definition of Homomorphism in Section 15.4. Then read Section 15.5 of Applied Discrete Structures up to, but not including, Subsection 15.5.2 Error Correction. After outlining the objectives behind coding theory we first consider how to effectively detect transmission errors.

statement.p: If you measure the distance between elements of a set, S, with a function d: S\times S \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, what general distance properties would you expect of this function?

section.p:
Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:
Interogating a Liar. I'm a liar, but not a big one. In my responses to your yes/no questions, I promise not to lie more than one time. I'm thinking of a number, either 0 or 1. How many yes/no questions do you need to ask in order to find out my number? Explain your logic.
The Hamming Distance, d_H, between two strings of bits with the same length is the number positions within the two strings where the strings differ. For instance, d_H(11101,10100)=2 because the two strings differ in positions 2 and 5. What is the minimal Hamming distance between any two strings in the set C =\{00000,11011,11100,00111\}?

li.p: Suppose a two bit message is encoded into a five bit message using the function e(b_{1}b_{2})=b_{1}b_{1}(b_{1}+_2 b_{2})b_{2}b_{2}. What matrix, G, has the property that e(b_{1}b_{2})=(b_{1} b_{2}) G?

Define the two functions g:\mathbb{Z}_2{}^3\rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2{}^4 and p:\mathbb{Z}_2{}^4\to \mathbb{Z}_2 by g(a_1,a_2,a_3) = (a_1,a_2,a_3 ,a_1+_2 a_2+_2a_3), and p(b_1,b_2,b_3,b_4)=b_1+b_2+b_3+b_4.
The values of g(a_1,a_2,a_3) and p(b_1,b_2,b_3,b_4) can be computed as matrix products. Determine the matrices.
Describe the function p \circ g. Is it a homomorphism?

Suppose we were to send three bits across a binary symmetric channel by first encoding the bits using the function g from the previous problem, producing a sequence of four bits. After receiving the four bits, the person at the receiving end applies the function p to those bits. What can we derive from the output of p?

ol.li: Linear Codes. Let m and n be positive integers. Suppose that G is an m \times n matrix of zeros and ones. Then we can can define a function e:\mathbb{Z}_2^m \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2^n by e(a)=a G where we take a \in \mathbb{Z}_2^m to be a 1\times m matrix and we perform mod 2 arithmetic in computing the product a G. Prove that e is a homomorphism.
